title: Characterizing the 3D Polar Texture of Ferroelectric Relaxors using Multislice Electron Ptychography
content: Relaxor ferroelectrics exhibit exceptional piezoelectric and dielectric properties, attributed to their intricate polar structure [1]. Since their discovery, the theoretical models of relaxor behavior have evolved considerably, starting from polar nano domains described by random field theory [2] to the description characterized by slush-like polar texture [3]. However, the validation of the atomic-scale model and efforts to unravel the interplay of chemical and structural order/disorder have been significantly hindered due to the lack of characterization techniques that can access sub-surface structure. For example, while scanning transmission electron microscopy offers localized exploration of nanoscale features [4], the projection of the three-dimensional (3D) crystal into 2D image introduces challenges in unambiguously determining chemistry and polar structure, as well as their correlation. In contrast, multislice electron ptychography (MEP) has emerged as a powerful tool to overcome these challenges [5, 6].
